content.description: Start up the hill from Antibro, at a small ledge which is follow right to the first bolt.  Move up the initial face past a bouldery move and then slightly left to a good left facing flake/corner.  From the top of this move back right onto a very thin face section.  Thin crimps give way to some strange, hard to read moves.  Sustained and excellent.

climbs.name: Lickety Split
climbs.fa: (TR) Chris Miller, September 2002; First Lead: Frank Dolan, Charlie Barrett, (Bolted by Russell Karchner)

content.description: 4 bolt variation to Cromagnon, not in my guidebook but a worthwhile harder lead if you're in the area (or a toprope after leading Cromagnon). Mostly fun 5.10 climbing with a distinct bouldery 5.12 crux on crimpy sidepulls where the wall visibly blanks out. Some may say 5.12b because of the shortness of the crux, but 5.12c seems pretty reasonable too when you're up there.
content.location: 5ft left of Cromagnon, then shares the last 3 bolts of that climb.

content.description: Sporty face, a bit wandery. Merges with a crack system towards the top in which optional gear can be placed.
content.protection: 7 bolts, opt. gear to 0.5" to fixed anchors.
content.location: Second line from the left, in between Black Lassie (bolted 10d on left) and Black Dihedral (10b trad corner). Lower off.

content.description: Start at the base of Black Dihedral and immediately move right onto the face.  Head up through a series of confusing moves and the crux, aiming for the obvious upper dihedral.  Cruise up this to the final roof which is pulled to the right.  Fun with micro-routefinding skills being useful.

Not a bad route, but probably the "worst" on the East face. This is really only due to the fact that it has only one hard move and the rest is cruiser.

Start up a right leaning, left facing flake/corner, followed by a quick crux up to the ledge. Traverse left to the dihedral and head straight up it to a strange reach out right for the anchors.

The fact that this is worst route on the wall is a testament to the quality of the climbing on the East face.

A great, varied climb up cracks and jugs.  Start at a crack below a roof.  Climb up and through the roof with great hand jams.  Good flakes lead up to a leftward traverse leading to the final crack.  Very fun climbing on great rock.

This is the farthest left climb and one of the best at the crag.  Start up a dihedral feature and then onto the face, following great pinch dikes up the black streaked rock.  An insecure, layback crux awaits near the top.  Quality.

Varied climbing, with somewhat tricky gear placements, up the corner to a distinct crux at a small roof just below the anchors. You'll need to employ all of your climbing skills on this one to succeed.
content.protection:
Gear to 3 inches, including wires

Bolted anchor/rap
content.location:
The obvious left-facing corner on the left end of the east face between

Grinder

on the right and

John Hartman's Proud Rock Climb

on the left.

content.description: Start a few feet left of Cromagnon at a right facing corner system.  Head up the awkward corner system to a ledge.  Traverse left on the ledge and head up at a crack/groove and slightly right to another right facing corner.  Next move back right and up through the crux bulge.  Varied and complex.
